section.title: Macaulay Duration
section.p: Frederick Macaulay, an economist, published in 1938 an extensive study of interest rate behavior going back to 1865. In his book, Some Theoretical Problems Suggested by the Movement of Interest Rates, Macaulay introduced a measurement of interest rate risk that has since become known as Macaulay duration (or just duration). While there is some variation in the notation, we will denote Macaulay duration by D.

introduction.p: This example is due to Broverman. Consider a 10-year loan of 100 with an effective annual interest rate of 10%. Compare the following two payback schedules:

li.p: Schedule 1: Pay the entire balance with interest (100(1.1)^{10} = 259.37) at the end of the 10-year term.
Schedule 2: Pay back the principal of 100 at the end of the first year, and pay all of the accumulated interest at the end of the 10-year term (which, in this case, amounts to 23.60).

task.p: Which one of these is "longer"? If we think about the payments as weights at their relative points on the timeline, which would have a later "center of gravity"? Explain.
Which one of these schedules would subject the lender to greater interest rate risk? Why?
The Macaulay duration D is going to be a weighted average. What do you think we are going to average? What do you think the weights might be?

section.p: Suppose we have a set of cash flows CF_i at times t_i. The Macaulay duration is the weighted average of the times t_i. The weight for t_i is the present value of cash flow CF_i, relative to the present value of the entire cash flow stream.

introduction.p: For each of the following cash flows, estimate whether the duration will be (i) closer to the beginning of the term, (ii) somewhere in the middle of the term, or (iii) closer to the end of the term. Do not perform any calculations, just select one of the three options. Justify your estimation.

task.p: Anticipated cash flows of 10,000 at the end of year 2, 150 at the end of year 3, and 500 at the end of year 10.
Anticipated cash flows of 750 each year for 4 years, 1000 each year for 3 years, and 900 at the end of year 8.

introduction.p: Let's define D by a formula. Assume we have times t_1, \ldots, t_n with cash flows CF_i taking place at time t_i.

task.p: Since D is a weighted average, first we find the formula for each weight. The weight \omega_i is the ratio of the present value of cash flow CF_i to the present value of the full cash flow stream. Find a formula for \omega_i.
Since D = \sum \omega_i t_i, we can write down an explicit formula for D. Write that formula down.
